instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.S4_PWR_EN: What is S4_PWR_EN? S4_PWR_EN turns on the S4 power rails. Signals ending in _EN enable whatever came before _EN in the signal name when the voltage of the signal is high. .
definitions.P3V3SUS_EN: What is P3V3SUS_EN? P3V3SUS_EN is a signal that turns on the PP3V3_SUS power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high..
definitions.P5VS4RS3_EN_R: What is P5VS4RS3_EN_R? P5VS4RS3_EN_R is an enable signal that turns on the PP5V_S4RS3 power rail. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. The _R means the signal is asserted when the voltage is high(3.3v). .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, No Power, Green Light Present
threads.message:
Working on a board that had liquid, but was cleaned "hard" by someone; i.e., it looks like it's gone through either 2-3 cleanings (lots of white scaly buildup on everything), or maybe a long cleaning (5-10 minutes) in an UC. I can still spot tiny indications of where the liquid was, but I'm pretty stumped by this one. I have some questions about diagnosing this:

1. This board has <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> (8.56v), 3v42 (3.44v), <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> (at <RESISTOR>R8141</RESISTOR>), <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>, etc.

2. Board is missing <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL>, etc. All S0 rails are missing, so board isn't getting to s0 of course.

3. On <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>: pin 4: .197v; pin 12: 3.42v; pin 21: 3.42v; pin 23: 3.3v. So I'm missing my EN1 (<SIGNAL>P5VS4RS3_EN_R</SIGNAL>) for <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>. Tracing this back...

4. <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is .201v and <SIGNAL>S4_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> is 0v. I believe these are both sent out at the same time, which means something earlier is likely missing...

5. Found I'm also missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> as well, but I do have <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> (3.42v), so sounds like my SUS signal is my issue here...(uh oh, hopefully not dead CPU!)

6. At <CHIP>U8130</CHIP>: pin1 is present (<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>), but I don't have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>. Looks like this is required before <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>, even, so I believe we need to start here, right?

7. Looking at <SIGNAL>P3V3SUS_EN</SIGNAL>...I've got 0v at both pins of <RESISTOR>R8190</RESISTOR>. So now I'm missing <SIGNAL>P3V3SUS_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>, which is where I get stuck. Really hoping it's not a dead CPU. Maybe a clock issue? No signs of liquid near clock, and my vrtc is proper, but maybe it's damaged anyway.

I replaced <CHIP>U8130</CHIP> to be safe, and no change. Still no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>, etc.

I think I've offered enough information on this one, but if not, please let me know. Seems I need to get my <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> situated first. If this is not correct, please let me know! Thanks, Duke and Aprendiz.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, No Power, Green Light Present
threads.message: Is it power cycling? Checked 32KHz from clock chip? Checked all rails for shorts? The usual corroded resistors around <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and the traces there.
